full_conversation: Therapist: Alright, Amira. Let's begin our imaginal exposure exercise. Remember, you can stop at any time. Are you ready to start?
Client: I... I think so. I'm nervous, but I'll try.
Therapist: That's understandable. Let's start with your SUDS rating. From 0 to 100, how distressed are you right now?
Client: Um, probably around 40. My stomach feels a bit tight.
Therapist: Okay. Take a deep breath and begin describing the memory when you're ready.

Client: (inhales deeply) It was a Friday night. I was 15. My parents were arguing again. I could hear them from my room. The shouting got louder, and then... (voice trembles) I heard a loud crash. I ran downstairs and saw my dad standing over my mom. She was on the floor, crying. There was a broken vase next to her. I... I froze. I didn't know what to do.
Therapist: How are you feeling now? SUDS rating?
Client: It's... it's gone up. Maybe 60? My heart is racing.
Therapist: That's okay. You're doing well. Continue when you're ready.

Client: (takes a shaky breath) My dad saw me and yelled at me to go back to my room. But I couldn't move. Mom was still on the floor, and she looked so scared. Dad started walking towards me, and I thought... I thought he might hurt me too. I've never seen him so angry before.
Therapist: SUDS rating now?
Client: It's... it's 75. My hands are shaking. I can almost smell the cologne my dad was wearing that night.
Therapist: You're doing great, Amira. Stay with the memory.

Client: (voice quivering) I backed away as he came closer. He grabbed my arm, hard. It hurt so much. I cried out, and that's when mom got up. She... she pushed herself between us. She told me to go to my room, that everything would be okay. But I knew it wouldn't be. I ran upstairs and locked myself in, but I could still hear them. The shouting, the crying... (starts sobbing)
Therapist: Take a moment. How's your SUDS now?
Client: (through tears) It's... it's 90. I feel like I can't breathe. My chest hurts.
Therapist: You're safe here, Amira. Keep breathing. What happened next?

Client: I... I curled up on my bed, covering my ears. But I could still hear them. It felt like hours. Eventually, it got quiet. Too quiet. I was so scared to leave my room. I kept thinking about mom, if she was okay. I... I felt so helpless.
Therapist: And your SUDS rating now?
Client: It's still high... maybe 85? My body feels tense all over.
Therapist: You're doing really well. Keep going.

Client: I must have fallen asleep at some point. When I woke up the next morning, everything seemed... normal. Like nothing had happened. Mom had bruises, but she smiled and said she fell. Dad acted like nothing was wrong. I... I felt so angry and confused. I wanted to scream, to tell someone, but... I was too afraid.
Therapist: How are you feeling now? SUDS?
Client: It's... it's coming down a bit. Maybe 70? I feel drained, but the tightness in my chest is easing.
Therapist: That's good. You've done really well, Amira. How do you feel about the exercise?
Client: It was... intense. Scary. But... I feel like I got through it. Is... is that normal?
Therapist: Absolutely. You showed a lot of strength today.
Client: (sighs) Thank you. I... I think I need a moment to just... breathe.
Therapist: Of course. Take all the time you need.
